originalTitle: Kenyans drop flowers for Valentine's bouquets of cash. Not everyone is impressed
title: Kenyans drop flowers for Valentine's bouquets of cash. Not everyone is impressed
content: Bouquets of cash have been blooming in popularity in Kenya but recent warnings may slow the trend.

originalTitle: Sudanese city had 6,000 killed in three days, UN says
title: Helping Our Friends in Sudan
content:
Hello, my wonderful friends all across Africa! Your special kid reporter is here with some news about our big African family. Today, we're thinking about a country called Sudan. It's a beautiful place with friendly people, just like where you live. Sometimes, grown-ups in some places have big problems. Right now, our friends in Sudan are having a very tough time. They need our kind thoughts and wishes for peace.

What is Happening in Sudan?

Imagine if your street suddenly became very noisy and scary. This is a little bit like what happened in a city in Sudan called El-Fasher. There was a lot of fighting between some groups of grown-ups. When grown-ups fight, it makes everyone very sad and scared. Many people, including children like you, had to leave their homes quickly. Their homes were not safe anymore. They had to go to new places to find safety. This means they left behind their toys, their beds, and sometimes even their friends and family. It was not a happy time for them. Many people got hurt, and everyone wanted the fighting to stop so they could be safe again. Did you know? Sudan is a very big country in North Africa. It has a long river called the Nile River, just like some other African countries!

Who are the Helpers?

Even when things are tough, there are always helpers! Many good people and groups want to make things better in Sudan. One very big helper group is called the United Nations, or the UN for short. Imagine the UN as a team of grown-ups from all over the world. They work hard to help people who are in trouble. They try to bring food, water, and medicine to places where people need it. The UN also tries to talk to the grown-ups who are fighting. They tell them to stop and make peace. They want everyone to live safely and happily. Doctors, nurses, and other kind people are also helping. They are like superheroes who rush to help those who are hurt or sick. Did you know? The United Nations wants to make the whole world a peaceful and fair place for everyone, especially children!

Why do Grown-Ups Fight?

Sometimes, grown-ups have big disagreements. They might not agree on how their country should be run. They might want different things for their people. When they can't talk and agree, sometimes they start to fight. This fighting is never good, and it makes many people suffer. It makes everyone sad and worried. Fighting means people can't go to school, can't play outside, and can't feel safe in their own homes. This is why peace is so important. We learn at home and at school that fighting is not the answer. Sharing, listening, and being kind are always the best ways to solve problems. Did you know? Even small acts of kindness, like sharing your toys or helping a friend, can make the world a more peaceful place!

What is a Safe Home?

A safe home is a place where you feel happy and protected. It's where you can play, learn, and sleep without any worries. Everyone in the world deserves to have a safe home. For our friends in El-Fasher and other parts of Sudan, their homes suddenly became unsafe. The noise and danger made it impossible to stay there. So, they had to pack very little and leave. They are looking for new safe places to stay, maybe with family or in special camps where helpers give them food and shelter. It's very brave of them to go through such a big change. We hope that soon, all the children and families in Sudan can go back to their safe homes, or find new ones where they can feel protected and happy again. Did you know? There are many different kinds of homes in Africa, from mud houses to big apartment buildings! But the most important thing is that a home is safe and full of love.

How Can We Help Our Friends?

Even though we might be far away, we can still help our friends in Sudan! We can send them our kindest thoughts and wishes. We can wish for peace and safety for them every day. Our grown-ups can also help. They can give money to organisations that send food, water, medicine, and doctors to Sudan. These helpers make sure people have what they need. We can also learn about peace. We can practice being kind to our friends, sharing our things, and helping others in our own communities. When we are kind, we are helping to build a more peaceful world. Every good thought and kind action makes a difference, big or small! It shows that we care about our big African family. Did you know? When you share your toys or a snack with a friend, you are showing kindness, which helps everyone feel happy and peaceful!

What is Peace?

Peace is a wonderful feeling! It means everyone is safe, happy, and friendly. It means there is no fighting or shouting, just playing, laughing, and learning. Imagine a playground where everyone shares the swings, takes turns on the slide, and helps each other up when they fall. That's peace! Peace is like a big, warm hug for everyone. It means that grown-ups can go to work, children can go to school, and families can be together without any worries. We all want peace for our friends in Sudan and for everyone in Africa and around the world. It is the best gift we can wish for. Did you know? The symbol for peace is often a white dove, which is a gentle bird. The colour white often means pureness and peace! Let's all keep our friends in Sudan in our thoughts. We hope they will soon find peace and safety. Thank you for listening, and remember to always be kind and spread peace wherever you go!
summary: Our friends in Sudan are having a tough time with fighting, making many people, including children, leave their homes, but helpers like the United Nations are working to bring peace and safety back to them.
whyMatters: This is important because everyone in our big African family deserves to feel safe and happy in their homes, and we want to send our good wishes and help to our friends in Sudan to find peace.

originalTitle: A seat at the table or on the menu? Africa grapples with the new world order
title: A seat at the table or on the menu? Africa grapples with the new world order
content: The US president has shaken up international relations and the continent is working out where it stands.

title: Rubio says US and Europe 'belong together' despite tensions

title: Gisèle Pelicot tells BBC: I felt crushed by horror - but I don't feel anger
content: In an extensive interview with Newsnight, the woman at the heart of France's biggest rape trial speaks about betrayal, healing and choosing the right path.

title: Police activity under way near Nancy Guthrie's home
content: A search has been carried out in Tuscon, Arizona, close to where the 84-year-old was abducted nearly two weeks ago.

originalTitle: Neto scores hat-trick as Chelsea see off Hull in FA Cup
title: Neto scores hat-trick as Chelsea see off Hull in FA Cup
content: A Pedro Neto hat-trick fires Chelsea through to the FA Cup fifth round with a comfortable win at Championship Hull City.

originalTitle: Wrexham beat Ipswich to progress to FA Cup fifth round
title: Wrexham beat Ipswich to progress to FA Cup fifth round
content: Wrexham book their place in the fifth round of the FA Cup for the first time in 29 years as they beat Championship rivals Ipswich Town at Stok Cae Ras.
